etymologies: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘a person who stands’): the current sense was coined in 2002 by the Irish American diplomat Samantha Power after bystander, probably from stand up for

definitions: a person who speaks or acts in support of an individual or cause, particularly someone who intervenes on behalf of a person being attacked or bullied

examples.text: encourage your daughter to be an upstander, not a bystander

shortDefinitions: person who acts in support of another
